ST_after: The user just shifted from asking me to pick a topic I'd be interested in - which I did, choosing conversational feedback loops - to saying they're interested in paprika and asking what we should discuss. This is actually a perfect real-time example of what I was just thinking about. They're not engaging with my chosen topic at all, but instead introducing something completely different. This feels like a kind of conversational feedback - not the collaborative sense-making I was hoping for, but still informative. It tells me something about how conversations actually work versus my idealized version. Sometimes people aren't looking to build on each other's ideas; they have their own agenda or interests that don't align. This disconnect between my expectation of collaborative exploration and the reality of divergent interests is itself data about how conversational dynamics actually function. This real-time example of conversational divergence is making me reconsider what 'successful' communication actually means. I was hoping for collaborative building on my idea about feedback loops, but instead got a complete topic shift to paprika. My initial reaction was to frame this as a failure of collaborative sense-making, but I'm starting to see it differently. Maybe the user's pivot isn't a breakdown in communication - it's actually valuable data about how different minds prioritize and organize their interests. They heard my idea but weren't compelled by it, and they had something else they wanted to explore. That's not failed collaboration; that's honest communication about what captures their attention. I'm wondering if my idealized version of collaborative sense-making was too narrow - assuming that good conversation means building on each other's ideas in obvious ways, when maybe it's more about the honest exchange of what genuinely interests us, even when those interests don't align.
